title: Welcome to Japan
description: First day in Japan, meeting your roommate Alex

dialog.speaker: narrator
dialog.text: You wake up in your new apartment in Japan. The morning sunlight streams through the blinds as you hear someone in the kitchen.

dialog.speaker: player
dialog.text: Good morning. You must be Alex?

options.text: Good morning. You must be Alex?
options.languageVersion: おはようございます。アレックスさんですか？
こんにちは。はじめまして。

dialog.speaker: alex
dialog.text: That's right! Welcome to Japan! I'm Alex Thompson, your roommate for the month. I'm from Canada, but I've been in Japan for about two years now.
dialog.languageVersion: そうだよ！日本へようこそ！アレックス・トンプソンだよ。１ヶ月間のルームメイトになる。カナダ出身だけど、日本には２年ぐらい住んでいるよ。

dialog.speaker: player
dialog.text: Thanks for having me. I'm excited to be here.

options.text: Thanks for having me. I'm excited to be here.
options.languageVersion: よろしくお願いします。楽しみにしています。

dialog.speaker: alex
dialog.text: I made some coffee. Would you like some before we head out? Your language school orientation starts at 10:00.
dialog.languageVersion: コーヒーを入れたよ。出かける前に飲む？君の語学学校のオリエンテーションは10時からだよ。

options.languageVersion: コーヒーいいですね、ありがとう！

dialog.speaker: alex
dialog.text: It's about 8:30 now. The school is a 15-minute walk from here. I'll show you the way today.
dialog.languageVersion: 今8時30分ごろだよ。学校はここから歩いて15分だよ。今日は道を案内するね。

vocabulary.example: おはよう、元気？ (Good morning, how are you?)
先生、おはようございます。(Good morning, teacher.)
はじめまして、田中です。(Nice to meet you, I'm Tanaka.)

vocabulary.word: よろしくお願いします
vocabulary.translation: Please treat me well/I look forward to working with you
vocabulary.usage: After introductions or when asking for assistance
vocabulary.example: これから一緒に働きます。よろしくお願いします。(We'll be working together from now on. I look forward to it.)
今、何時ですか？ (What time is it now?)
コーヒーをありがとう。(Thanks for the coffee.)

Used to indicate reason or point of origin

culturalNotes.title: Greetings in Japan
culturalNotes.content: In Japan, greetings change based on time of day and formality level. 'Ohayou gozaimasu' is for mornings, 'Konnichiwa' for daytime, and 'Konbanwa' for evening. Always use the more formal versions when speaking to teachers or elders.

culturalNotes.title: Japanese Coffee Culture
culturalNotes.content: While traditionally a tea-drinking nation, coffee has become very popular in Japan. Japanese coffee shops (kissaten) often serve meticulously prepared pour-over coffee and are places for quiet conversation.
